article.title: Ethnocentrism
article.paragraph: Ethnocentrismis judging another culture solely by the values and standards of one's own culture.cite bookThinking like an Anthropologist: A practical introduction to Cultural AnthropologyJohn T. OmohundroMcGraw Hill0-07-319580-4http://books.google.com/?id2008Page neededNovember 2012Ethnocentric individuals judge other groups relative to their own ethnic group or culture, especially with concern forlanguage, behavior, customs, andreligion. These ethnic distinctions and subdivisions serve to define eachethnicity's uniquecultural identity.cite bookSociology: Understanding a Diverse SocietyMargaret L. Andersen, Howard Francis TaylorWadsworth0-534-61716-6http://books.google.com/?id2006Ethnocentrism may be overt or subtle, and while it is considered a natural proclivity of human psychology, it has developed a generally negative connotation.Shimp, Terence. article.heading: Origins of the concept and its study
article.paragraph: William G. Sumnercoined the term "ethnocentrism" upon observing the tendency for people to differentiate between thein-groupand others. He defined it as "the technical name for the view of things in which one's own group is the center of everything, and all others are scaled and rated with reference to it."cite bookRobert King MertonRobert K. Merton[[Piotr Sztompka]]On social structure and sciencehttp://books.google.com/books?id1996University of Chicago Press978-0-226-52070-4248He further characterized it as often leading to pride, vanity, beliefs of one's own group's superiority, and contempt of outsiders.Sumner, W. G.Folkways. New York: Ginn, 1906.Robert K. Mertoncomments that Sumner's additional characterization robbed the concept of some analytical power because, Merton argues, centrality and superiority are often correlated, but need to be kept analytically distinct.

AnthropologyAnthropologistssuch asFranz BoasandBronislaw Malinowskiargued that any human science had to transcend the ethnocentrism of the scientist. Both urged anthropologists to conductethnographyethnographicfield workfieldworkin order to overcome their ethnocentrism. Boas developed the principle ofcultural relativismand Malinowski developed the theory ofstructural functionalismfunctionalismas guides for producing non-ethnocentric studies of different cultures. Classic examples of anti-ethnocentric anthropology includeMargaret Mead'sComing of Age in Samoa(1928), Malinowski'sThe Sexual Life of Savages in North-Western Melanesia(1929), andRuth Benedict'sRuth Benedict#Patterns of CulturePatterns of Culture(1934). (Mead and Benedict were two of Boas's students.)
article.heading: Anthropology
article.paragraph: People born into a particular culture that grow up absorbing the values and behaviors of the culture will develop a worldview that considers their culture to be the norm.Stanley S. Seidner, Ethnicity,Language, and Power from a Psycholinguistic Perspective. Bruxelles: Centre de recherche sur le pluralinguisme, 1982.If people then experience other cultures that have different values and normal behaviors, they will find that the thought patterns appropriate to their birth culture and the meanings their birth culture attaches to behaviors are not appropriate for the new cultures. However, since people are accustomed to their birth culture, it can be difficult for them to see the behaviors of people from a different culture from the viewpoint of that culture rather than from their own.Seidner, Ethnicity,Language, and Power.....

Examples of ethnocentrism includereligiocentricconstructs claiming adivineassociation like "divine nation", "Pledge of AllegianceOne Nation under God", "God's Own Country", "God's Chosen People", and "God's Promised Land".cite bookWilliam A. HavilandHarald E. L. PrinsDana WalrathBunny McBrideThe Essence of Anthropologyhttp://books.google.com/books?id2009Cengage Learning978-0-495-59981-4159
InPrecarious Life,Judith Butlerdiscusses recognizing the Other in order to sustain the Self and the problems of not being able to identify the Other. Butler writes:

list.listitem: [I]dentification always relies upon a difference that it seeks to overcome, and that its aim is accomplished only by reintroducing the difference it claims to have vanquished. The one with whom I identify is not me, and that "not being me" is the condition of the identification. Otherwise, as Jacqueline Rose reminds us, identification collapses into identity, which spells the death of identification itself.cite bookButlerJudith2004Precarious Life: The Powers of Mourning and Violencehttp://books.google.com.au/books?idNew YorkVerso145–14612 April 2014

article.heading: Biology and evolutionary theory
article.paragraph: A 2011 paper inPNASsuggested that ethnocentrism may be mediated by theoxytocinhormone. It found that inrandomized controlled trials"oxytocin creates intergroup bias because oxytocin motivates in-group favoritism and, to a lesser extent, out-group derogation".De Dreu, Carsten K. W.,"Oxytocin promotes human ethnocentrism,"Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 10 January 2011.

InThe Selfish Gene, evolutionary biologistRichard Dawkinswrites that "Blood-feuds and inter-clan warfare are easily interpretable in terms ofW. D. HamiltonHamilton'skin selectiongenetic theory."cite bookRichard DawkinsThe selfish genehttp://books.google.com/books?id2006Oxford University Press978-0-19-929115-199Simulation-based experiments inevolutionary game theoryhave attempted to provide an explanation for the selection of ethnocentric-strategy phenotypes.Cite journal10.1177/0022002706293470HammondR.
